'''Calvin Lunsford Beale''' (6 June 1923 – 2 September 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[demographer]] who specialized in rural population trends. He first identified a reverse in population decline in some rural areas, and his work led to development of the [[Beale code]] for categorizing rural development.

==Life and career==
He was born in Northeast [[Washington, D.C.]] on June 6, 1923. He graduated from [[Eastern High School (Washington, D.C.)|Eastern High School]] and the [[University of the District of Columbia#History|Wilson Teachers College]].<ref name="wapoobit"/>

[[File:OneidaCoCourthouse-Beale.jpg|thumb|right|Calvin Beale's 1998 photograph of the [[Oneida County Courthouse (Rome, New York)|Oneida County Courthouse]] in [[Rome, New York]] (1851). Beale took hundreds of courthouse photographs during his long career as a demographer.|alt=Photograph.]]
After earning a master's degree in [[sociology]] from the [[University of Wisconsin]], he worked for 50 years at the [[United States Department of Agriculture]].<ref name="nytobit">Barringer, Felicity (September 2, 2008). [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/03/us/03beale.html Calvin L. Beale, Demographer With a Feel for Rural America, Dies at 85.] ''[[New York Times]]''</ref><ref name="wildman2008">Wildman Jim (September 20, 2008). [http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94826029 Traveling The Rural Road With Calvin Beale.] ''[[National Public Radio]]''</ref> In addition to his work as a demographer, Beale is noted for his many photographs of county courthouses from around the United States taken during his travels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://webarchives.cdlib.org/sw15d8pg7m/http://ers.usda.gov/Briefing/Population/Photos/ |title=Beale's county courthouse photo archive |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture - Economic Research Service |date=October 31, 2008 }}</ref>

Beale died of [[colon cancer]] in [[Washington, D.C.]].<ref name="wapoobit">Schudel, Matt (September 14, 2008). [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/13/AR2008091302354.html Demographer Looked Past the Numbers To Discover the Heart of the Heartland.] ''[[Washington Post]]''</ref>
